revision.text:
[[File:Official Horse States with Pending.svg|thumb|A map showing the states with official state horses marked in red and those with proposed designations marked in yellow|alt=A map of the United States with Alabama, Florida, Idaho, Kentucky, Maryland, Massachusetts, Missouri, New Jersey, North Carolina, North Dakota, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas and Vermont marked in red to designate the states with official horse breeds or states that have horses or horse breeds as their official state animal. Arizona and Oregon are marked in yellow to designate that they have had proposed state horse breeds.]] Twelve U.S. states have designated a [[horse breed]] as the official '''state horse'''. The first state horse was designated in Vermont in 1961. The most recent state designations occurred in 2010, when [[North Carolina]] and [[South Carolina]] both declared state breeds. There have been proposals to designate a state horse in [[Oregon]] as well as in [[Arizona]] (where an ongoing campaign sought to designate the [[Colonial Spanish Horse]] as the state horse prior to the state centennial in 2012), but neither proposal is yet successful.{{cite web|url=http://www.arizonahorseproject.com/About.htm|title=About Us|publisher=Arizona Colonial Spanish Horse Project|accessdate=February 10, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707161826/http://www.arizonahorseproject.com/About.htm|archivedate=July 7, 2011|df=}} In one state, [[North Dakota]], the state horse is officially designated the "'''honorary state equine'''.""[http://www.nd.gov/content.htm?parentCatID=75&id=State%20Equine North Dakota State Equine]," State of North Dakota. Two additional states have not designated a specific state horse, but have designed a horse or horse breed as its official [[List of U.S. state animals|state animals]]: the horse in [[New Jersey]] and the [[Morgan horse|Morgan]] horse breed in [[Vermont]]. Some breeds, such as the [[American Quarter Horse]] in [[Texas]] and the Morgan horse in Vermont and [[Massachusetts]], were named as the state horse because of the close connection between the history of the breed and the state. Others, including the [[Tennessee Walking Horse]] and the [[Missouri Fox Trotter]], include the state in the official breed name. School children have been persuasive lobbyists for the cause of some state horses, such as the [[Colonial Spanish Horse]] being named the state horse of North Carolina due to the presence of the Spanish-descended [[Banker horse]]s in the [[Outer Banks]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wvec.com/news/local/NC-okays-Outer-Banks-wild-horses-as-state-horse-95446659.html|title=NC okays Outer Banks mustangs as state horse|date=June 2, 2010|accessdate=March 19, 2011|publisher=WVEC Television, Inc|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605233722/http://www.wvec.com/news/local/NC-okays-Outer-Banks-wild-horses-as-state-horse-95446659.html|archivedate=June 5, 2010|df=}} while others have been brought to official status through the lobbying efforts of their [[breed registry|breed registries]]. Official state horses are one of many [[Lists of United States state insignia|state symbols]] officially designated by states. Each state has its own [[Flags of the U.S. states|flag]] and [[Seals of the U.S. states|state seal]], and many states also designate other symbols, including animals, plants, and foods. Such items usually are designated because of their ties to the culture or history of that particular state. In addition to being state symbols in their own right, horses have also appeared in state symbols; for example, a horse's head appears on the [[Seal of New Jersey]]. __TOC__ {{clear}} ==State horses== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- " ! scope="col"| State ! scope="col"| Breed ! scope="col"; class="unsortable"| Description ! scope="col"; class="unsortable"| Image ! scope="col" |Year designated ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Ref |- ! scope="row"| [[Alabama]] | [[Racking Horse]] || The Racking Horse is a breed of horse known for its [[ambling gait]]. The [[breed association]] is headquartered in [[Decatur, Alabama]]. || {{center|–}} || 1975 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.rackinghorse.com/history.html|title=History|publisher=Racking Horse Breeders' Association of America|accessdate=February 5, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128022253/http://rackinghorse.com/history.html|archivedate=November 28, 2010|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Florida]] | [[Florida Cracker Horse]] || The Florida Cracker Horse was first brought to what is now Florida in the 1500s by Spanish explorers, and it played a large part in the development of the state's cattle and general agriculture industries.|| [[File:Remington A cracker cowboy.jpg|150 px]] || 2008 ||{{cite web|url=http://flhouse.gov/Sections/Bills/billsdetail.aspx?BillId=37223&SessionId=57|title=CS/CS/HB 131 – State Symbols|accessdate=October 5, 2010|publisher=Florida House of Representatives}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.floridacrackerhorses.com/history.htm|title=History of the Cracker Horse|publisher=Florida Cracker Horse Association|accessdate=March 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324221722/http://www.floridacrackerhorses.com/history.htm|archivedate=March 24, 2011|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Idaho]] | [[Appaloosa]] || The Appaloosa has made a substantial contribution to Idaho history, mainly through its association with the [[Nez Perce tribe|Nez Perce Indian tribe]]. || [[File:THIEL 619.jpg|150 px]] || 1975 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.appaloosa.com/association/history.htm|title=Appaloosa History|publisher=Appaloosa Horse Club|accessdate=February 5, 2011}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Kentucky]] | [[Thoroughbred]] || The Thoroughbred is the center of a multi-billion dollar breeding and racing industry in Kentucky. || [[File:Horseracing Churchill Downs.jpg|150 px]] || 1996 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.lrc.ky.gov/kidspages/symbols.htm|title=State Symbols|publisher=Kentucky Legislative Research Commission|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}
|- ! scope="row"| [[Maryland]] | [[Thoroughbred]] || Maryland has a long history of breeding and racing Thoroughbreds, and today maintains an extensive network of breeding farms, training centers and racecourses.|| [[File:Horse-racing-4.jpg|150 px]] || 2003 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.msa.md.gov/msa/mdmanual/01glance/symbols/html/horse.html|title=Maryland State Horse – Thoroughbred Horse|work=State Symbols|publisher=State of Maryland|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}
{{cite web|url=http://marylandthoroughbred.com/breeders/|title=Breeders Association|publisher=Maryland Horse Breeders Association|accessdate=March 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110420003846/http://marylandthoroughbred.com/breeders/|archivedate=April 20, 2011|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Massachusetts]] | [[Morgan horse|Morgan]] || The [[foundation bloodstock|foundation sire]] of the Morgan breed, named [[Figure (horse)|Figure]], was born in [[West Springfield, Massachusetts]] in 1789. || [[File:American Morgan Horse cropped.jpg|150 px]] || 1970 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.sec.state.ma.us/cis/cismaf/mf1a.htm|title=Part One: Concise Facts|publisher=Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=February 5, 2011}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Missouri]] | [[Missouri Fox Trotter]] || The Fox Trotter is a [[gaited breed]] developed in the Missouri [[Ozarks]]. || [[File:Quick Trigger Missouri Fox Trotter.jpeg|150 px]] || 2002 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.mfthba.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=108&Itemid=55|title=About the Missouri Fox Trotter Horse Breed|publisher=Missouri Fox Trotting Horse Breed Association|accessdate=February 5, 2011}} |- ! scope="row"| [[New Jersey]] | [[Horse]] (state animal) || As of the designation of the horse as the state animal, New Jersey contained over 4,500 horse farms housing almost 40,000 horses and played host to a horse industry that extensively contributed to the preservation of natural lands in the state.|| [[File:Mangalarga Marchador.jpg|150 px]] || 1977 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.state.nj.us/njfacts/horse1.htm|title=Chapter 173, Laws of 1977|publisher=State of New Jersey|accessdate=March 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001025138/http://www.state.nj.us/njfacts/horse1.htm|archivedate=October 1, 2011|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[North Carolina]] | [[Colonial Spanish Horse|Colonial Spanish Mustang]] ||This state breed references the [[Banker horse]] of the [[Outer Banks]], descended from Spanish stock. || [[File:SpanishMustangsOfCorolla.jpg|150 px]] || 2010 || |- ! scope="row"| [[North Dakota]] | [[Nokota horse|Nokota]] (honorary equine) || The Nokota developed in the [[badlands]] of southwestern North Dakota, and are named after the [[Sioux|Nakota]] Indian tribe that inhabited the area.|| [[File:Nokota Horses.jpg|150 px]] || 1993 ||{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C_hqb0DVR-AC&pg=PA195&dq=Nokota+horse#v=onepage&q=Nokota%20horse&f=false|pages=192–195|title=Storey's Illustrated Guide to 96 Horse Breeds of North America|author=Dutson, Judith|publisher=Storey Publishing|year=2005|isbn=1-58017-613-5}} |- ! scope="row"| [[South Carolina]] | [[Carolina Marsh Tacky]] || The Marsh Tacky was developed in the swampy [[South Carolina Lowcountry|Low Country region of South Carolina]], and has played an integral part in the state's history.|| [[File:Carolina Marsh Tacky.jpg|150px]] || 2010 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.marshtacky.org/State-Horse.php|publisher=Carolina Marsh Tacky Association|title=State Heritage Horse|accessdate=February 4, 2011}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.marshtacky.org/History-of-the-Breed.php|title=The Marsh Tacky Horse – Yesterday and Today|publisher=Carolina Marsh Tacky Association|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Tennessee]] | [[Tennessee Walking Horse]] || The Tennessee Walker is a [[gaited breed]] initially developed in middle Tennessee.|| [[File:MiltonHorseShow.jpg|150 px]] || 2000 || {{cite web|url=http://www.state.tn.us/sos/bluebook/07-08/46-Symbols%20&%20Honors.pdf|title=Tennessee Symbols and Honors|work=[[Tennessee Blue Book]]|publisher=State of Tennessee |accessdate=February 5, 2011|format=PDF}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.twhbea.com/breed/history.php|title=History and Description|publisher=Tennessee Walking Horse Breeders' and Exhibitors' Association|accessdate=March 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717120734/http://www.twhbea.com/breed/history.php|archivedate=July 17, 2011|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Texas]] | [[American Quarter Horse]] || The history of the Quarter Horse is closely intertwined with that of Texas, where the breed was used for ranching and racing. The [[American Quarter Horse Association]] is headquartered in [[Amarillo, Texas]].|| [[File:Buckskin mare left flank.jpg|150 px]] || 2009 ||{{cite journal|url=http://www.thehorse.com/ViewArticle.aspx?ID=14747|title=Quarter Horse Named Official State Horse of Texas|date=August 19, 2009|accessdate=February 5, 2011|journal=The Horse|registration=yes}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Vermont]] | [[Morgan horse|Morgan]] (state animal) || The Morgan breed was developed mainly in Vermont, where the [[foundation bloodstock|founding stallion]], [[Figure (horse)|Figure]], lived most of his life and died in 1821.|| [[File:American Morgan Horse cropped.jpg|150 px]] || 1961 ||{{cite web|url=http://libraries.vermont.gov/sites/libraries/files/html/horse.htm|title=State Animal: Morgan Horse|accessdate=February 5, 2011|publisher=State of Vermont|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110093117/http://libraries.vermont.gov/sites/libraries/files/html/horse.htm|archivedate=November 10, 2010|df=}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.morganhorse.com/about_the_morgan/history/|title=History|publisher=American Morgan Horse Association|accessdate=March 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225012355/http://www.morganhorse.com/about_the_morgan/history|archivedate=February 25, 2011|df=}} |} ===Proposed breeds=== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center; width:100%;" |- " ! scope="col" | State ! scope="col" | Breed ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Description ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Image ! scope="col" |Year proposed ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| Ref |- ! scope="row"| [[Arizona]] | [[Colonial Spanish Horse]] || The Colonial Spanish Horse has a long history in Arizona, mainly through the Wilbur-Cruce strain originally bred near [[Arivaca, Arizona|Arivaca]]. || [[File:Gypsypasturepic1.jpg|150 px]] ||2010 (re-proposed in 2011) ||
{{cite web|url=http://www.arizonahorseproject.com/History.htm|title=History of the Horses|publisher=Arizona's Colonial Spanish Horse Project|accessdate=March 17, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707161834/http://www.arizonahorseproject.com/History.htm|archivedate=July 7, 2011|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Oregon]] | [[Kiger Mustang]] || The Kiger Mustang is a strain of Mustang found in a feral state only in southeastern Oregon. || [[File:Mesteno.jpg|150 px]] || 2001 ||{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DHUVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mesDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5406,5369811|title=Senator trots out horse nominee|date=January 23, 2001|work=The Register-Guard|last=Steves|first=David|accessdate=November 1, 2009|location=Eugene, Oregon}} |} ==State symbols== Horses, both official state horses and not, are present in the emblems of several states. {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align: center" |- " !scope="col" | State !scope="col" | Symbol !scope="col" class="unsortable"| Image !scope="col" | Date !scope="col" class="unsortable"| Ref |- ! scope="row"| [[Delaware]] | [[50 State Quarters|State quarter]] – [[Caesar Rodney]] on horseback || [[File:1999 DE Proof.png|150 px]] || 1999 || {{cite web|url=http://www.usmint.gov/historianscorner/?action=coinDetail&id=29142|title=Delaware State Quarter – 1999|publisher=United States Mint|accessdate=March 16, 2011}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Idaho]] | [[Vehicle registration plates of Idaho|License plate]] – [[Appaloosa]] || {{center|–}} ||2003 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.legislature.idaho.gov/idstat/Title49/T49CH4SECT49-420D.htm|title=Title 49: Motor Vehicles, Chapter 4: Motor Vehicle Registration, 49-420D: Appaloosa License Plates|publisher=Idaho Legislature|accessdate=March 19, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220191302/http://www.legislature.idaho.gov/idstat/Title49/T49CH4SECT49-420D.htm#|archive-date=2010-12-20|dead-url=yes|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Kentucky]] | [[50 State Quarters|State quarter]] – [[Thoroughbred]] || [[File:2001 KY Proof.png|150 px]] || 2001 ||{{cite web|url=http://www.sos.ky.gov/kids/all/symbols/horse.htm|title=State Horse|publisher=Commonwealth of Kentucky|accessdate=April 12, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130607160104/http://www.sos.ky.gov/kids/all/symbols/horse.htm|archivedate=June 7, 2013|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Maryland]] | [[Seal of Maryland|State Seal]] – Knight on horseback || [[File:Seal of Maryland (obverse).png|150 px]]|| 1969 ||{{cite web|url=http://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/01glance/html/symbols/obverse.html|title=State Seal|publisher=State of Maryland|accessdate=April 12, 2014}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Nevada]] | [[50 State Quarters|State quarter]] – [[Mustang]] || [[File:2006 NV Proof.png|150 px]] || 2006 ||{{cite journal|journal=Numismatist|title=Wild at Heart: Mustangs outran other candidates for the Nevada quarter|author=Aldrich, Sean|date=February 2006|page=40|url=http://www.money.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=State_Quarters&Template=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=5851|accessdate=February 10, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225201635/http://www.money.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=State_Quarters&Template=%2FCM%2FContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=5851|archivedate=December 25, 2010|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[New Jersey]] | [[New Jersey State Seal|State seal]] and [[coat of arms]] – Horse || [[File:Seal of New Jersey.svg|150 px]] || 1928 ||{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ySeaRMwQP7wC&pg=PA1&lpg=PA1&dq=proposed+horse+breeds+as+state+symbols&source=bl&ots=3zyhFfR7cv&sig=Ayh2KSOTXC9_3uOHmrx2qErG03c&hl=en&ei=zJZNTdi6FobGgAepzaHoDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CBsQ6AEwATgo#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=1|author=Zatz, Arline|title=Horsing Around in New Jersey: The Horse Lover's Guide to Everything Equine|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-8135-3334-1}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.state.nj.us/njfacts/seal.htm|title=The Great Seal of the State of New Jersey|publisher=State of New Jersey|accessdate=March 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110503224045/http://www.state.nj.us/njfacts/seal.htm|archivedate=May 3, 2011|df=}} |- ! scope="row"| [[Pennsylvania]] | [[Coat of arms]] and [[Flag of Pennsylvania|flag]] – Horses || [[File:Flag of Pennsylvania.svg|150 px]] || {{sort|1875|Coat of arms: 1875
Flag: 1907}} ||{{cite web|url=http://www.phmc.state.pa.us/bah/pahist/symbols.asp?secid=31 |title= Pennsylvania: Past and Present – Symbols |accessdate=March 16, 2011 |publisher=Pennsylvania Historical and Museum Commission |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071014215922/http://www.phmc.state.pa.us/bah/pahist/symbols.asp?secid=31|archivedate = October 14, 2007}} |} ==See also== *[[Lists of U.S. state animals]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Horses of the United States}} {{state symbols}} {{state insignia}} {{USStateLists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Horses in the United States|.States]] [[Category:Lists of United States state symbols|Horses]] [[Category:Lists of animals of the United States|Horses]] [[Category:Horses in culture and religion]]

revision.text:
{{For|the Canadian Minister of Transport 1942|Pierre Cardin (politician)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox fashion designer |image=Pierre Cardin 2010.jpg |caption=Cardin in 2010 |name=Pierre Cardin |nationality=Italian and French |birth_date=Pietro Cardin
{{Birth date and age|df=yes|1922|7|2}} |birth_place=[[San Biagio di Callalta]], Italy |death_date= |death_place= ||awards=[[Commander (order)|Commander]] of the [[Order of Cultural Merit (Monaco)|Order of Cultural Merit]] (2007) |}} {{Infobox company | name = The House of Cardin | logo = | type = Private | foundation = 1950 | founder = Pierre Cardin | location_city = Paris | location_country = France | key_people = Pierre Cardin | industry = Fashion | products = | revenue = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | homepage = [http://www.pierrecardin.com pierrecardin.com] | footnotes = }} '''Pierre Cardin''' ({{IPA-fr|pjɛʁ kaʁdɛ̃|lang}}; born '''Pietro Cardin'''; 2 July 1922){{cite web|url=http://pierrecardin.com/wp-content/themes/pc/res/pdf/bio-pierre-cardin-EN.pdf |title= pierre cardin biography |publisher=pierrecardin.com|access-date= 1 Aug 2017}} is a French fashion designer.http://pierrecardin.com.cn/wordpress/?page_id=29&lang=fr{{cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=8287&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html|title=UNESCO Celebrity Advocates: Pierre Cardin|work=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|accessdate=2 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091111121349/http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID%3D8287%26URL_DO%3DDO_TOPIC%26URL_SECTION%3D201.html|archivedate=11 November 2009|df=dmy-all}} Cardin is known for his [[avant-garde]] style and his [[Space Age]] designs. He prefers [[geometry|geometric]] shapes and motifs, often ignoring the female form. He advanced into [[unisex]] fashions, sometimes experimental, and not always practical. He founded his fashion house in 1950 and introduced the "bubble dress" in 1954. He was designated [[UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador]] in 1991.{{cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=8287&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html|title=UNESCO Celebrity Advocates: Pierre Cardin|work=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|accessdate=2 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091111121349/http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID%3D8287%26URL_DO%3DDO_TOPIC%26URL_SECTION%3D201.html|archivedate=11 November 2009|df=dmy-all}} On 16 October 2009, Cardin was nominated [[FAO Goodwill Ambassador|Goodwill Ambassador]] of the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) of the United Nations.{{cite web|title=Meet the Goodwill Ambassadors: Pierre Cardin|url=http://www.fao.org/getinvolved/ambassadors/ambassadors/ambassadors-pierrecardin/en/|work=The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|accessdate=2 July 2010}} ==Career== [[File:1968 Pierre Cardin dress, pink heat moulded Dynel.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Pierre Cardin dress, heat-moulded Dynel, 1968]] [[File:Pierre Cardin ball pens.jpg|thumb|Pierre Cardin ball pens]] Cardin was born in [[San Biagio di Callalta]] near [[Treviso]]. Cardin’s parents were wealthy landowners, but to escape [[Fascism#Fascist violence, 1922|fascism]] they left Italy and settled in France in 1924.Hesse, J. (2010). Pierre Cardin: 60 years of innovation. New York: Assouline. His father, a wealthy [[French wine]] merchant, wished him to study architecture, but from childhood he was interested in dressmaking.http://0-academic.eb.com.library.scad.edu/levels/collegiate/article/Pierre-Cardin/20295 Cardin was educated in central France. Beginning his career early, at age 14 he worked as a clothier’s apprentice, learning the basics of fashion design and construction. In 1939, he left home to work for a tailor in [[Vichy]], where he began making suits for women. During [[World War II]], he worked in the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]], launching [[humanitarian]] interests that continue to this day.[http://mid-centuryonline.com/blog/pierre-cardin-biography/ ''Mid-Century Online Magazine'', Pierre Cardin, 6 July 2012] Cardin moved to Paris in 1945. There, he studied architecture and worked with the fashion house of [[Jeanne Paquin|Paquin]] after World War II. He worked with [[Elsa Schiaparelli]] until he became head of [[Christian Dior]]'s tailleure atelier in 1947, but was denied work at [[Balenciaga]]. Cardin founded his own house in 1950. His career was launched when he designed about 30 of the costumes for "the party of the century", a [[masquerade ball]] at [[Palazzo Labia]] in Venice on 3 September 1951, hosted by the palazzo's owner, [[Carlos de Beistegui]]. He began with [[haute couture]] in 1953. Cardin was the first couturier to turn to Japan as a [[fashion design|high fashion]] market when he travelled there in 1959. In 1959, he was expelled from the [[Fédération française de la couture|Chambre Syndicale]] for launching a [[ready-to-wear]] collection for the [[Printemps]] department store as the first [[couturier]] in Paris, but was soon reinstated. [[File:Pierre Cardin-Sculptures Utilitaires-Cobra Table and Chair.jpg|thumb|upright|Pierre Cardin - Cobra Table and Chair]] During the 1960s, Cardin began a practice that is now commonplace by creating the system of licences that he was to apply to fashion. A clothing collection launched around this period surprised all by displaying the designer’s logo on the garments for the first time. As haute couture began to decline, ready-to-wear soared as well as Cardin's designs. He was the first to combine the "mini" and the "maxi" skirts of the 1970s. He introduced a new hemline that had long pom-pom panels or fringe that swayed as the body moved. Beginning in the 1970s, Cardin set another new trend: "mod chic". This trend holds true for form or for a combination of forms, which did not exist at the time. He was the first to combine extremely short and ankle length pieces. He made dresses with slits and batwing sleeves with dimensions, and mixed circular movement and gypsy skirts with structured tops. These creations allowed for the geometric shapes that captivated him to be contrasted, with both circular and straight lines. Cardin was an icon for starting this popular fashion movement of the early seventies.Längle, E. (2005). Pierre Cardin: fifty years of fashion and design. London: Thames & Hudson. Cardin was fascinated with adventure. Enthralled with the idea of putting a man on the moon, Cardin is the only man in history to have tried on the original space suit worn by the first human to set foot on the moon, Neil Armstrong. Cardin loved the space suit so much, he created his own design for NASA in 1970. Cardin resigned from the Chambre Syndicale in 1966 and began showing his collections in his own venue, the "Espace Cardin" (opened 1971) in Paris, formerly the "Théâtre des Ambassadeurs", near the [[U.S. Embassy, Paris|Embassy of the United States in Paris]]. The Espace Cardin is also used to promote new artistic talents, like theater ensembles, musicians, and others. He was also contacted by [[Pakistan International Airlines]] to design uniforms for the flag carrier. The uniforms were introduced in 1966 to 1971 and became an instant hit.{{cite news|url=http://archives.dawn.com/weekly/dmag/archive/030504/dmag7.htm |title=Pierre Cardin comes to PIA |journal=Dawn Magazine |first=Omar |last=Kureishi |date=4 May 2003 |accessdate=26 March 2012 }} In 1971, Cardin redesigned the [[Barong Tagalog]], a national costume of [[the Philippines]], by opening the front, removing the cuffs that needed [[cufflink]]s, flaring the sleeves, and minimizing the embroidery. It was also tapered to the body, in contrast with the traditional loose-fitting design and it also had a thicker collar with sharp and pointed cuffs. A straight-cut design was favored by [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Ferdinand Marcos]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBdpE-aUchkC&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=pierre+cardin+ferdinand+marcos |title=The Politics of Dress in Asia and the Americas |page=31 |editor-last=Edwards |editor-first=Louise |editor2-last=Roces |editor2-first=Mina |publisher=Sussex Academic Press |year=2010 |isbn=978-1-84519-399-7 |accessdate=2 July 2011 }} In 1975 Cardin opened his first furniture boutique on rue du Faubourg-Saint-Honore. His furniture designs were highly inspired by his fashion designs. In both 1977 and 1979 he was awarded the Cartier Golden Thimble by French haute couture for most creative collection of the season. He was a member of the Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture et du Prêt-à-Porter from 1953 to 1993. Like many other designers today, Cardin decided in 1994 to show his collection only to a small circle of selected clients and journalists. After a break of 15 years, he showed a new collection to a group of 150 journalists at his bubble home in Cannes. ==Brand== Pierre Cardin used his name as a brand, initially a prestigious fashion brand, then in the 1960s expanded successfully into perfumes and cosmetics. From about 1988 the brand was [[License#Trademark and brand licensing|licensed]] extensively, and appeared on "wildly nonadjacent products such as baseball caps and cigarettes". A 2005 article in the Harvard Business Review commented that the extension into perfumes and cosmetics was successful as the premium nature of the Pierre Cardin brand transferred well into these new, adjacent categories, but that the owners of the brand mistakenly attributed this to the brand's strength rather than to its fit with the new product categories. The extensive licensing eroded the brand's credibility, but brought in much revenue; in 1986 ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'' (WWD) estimated Cardin’s annual income at over [[US$]]10 million. 1995 quotes from WWD included "Pierre Cardin—he has sold his name for toilet paper. At what point do you lose your identity?" and "Cardin’s cachet crashed when his name appeared on everything from key chains to pencil holders". However, the Cardin name was still very profitable, although the indiscriminate licensing approach was considered a failure.{{cite web |url=https://hbr.org/2005/12/how-not-to-extend-your-luxury-brand |title=How Not to Extend Your Luxury Brand |website=Harvard Business Review|date=December 2005|author=Mergen Reddy and Nic Terblanche|accessdate= 6 May 2017}}{{cite web |url=http://www.highsnobiety.com/2015/11/23/digging-deeper-pierre-cardin/ |title=Digging Deeper - Pierre Cardin's Demise to "Licensing King"|website=Highsnobiety.com |author=Jason Dike|date=23 November 2015|accessdate= 6 May 2017}} In 2011 Cardin tried to sell his business, valuing it at €1 billion, although the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' considered it to be worth about a fifth of that amount. Ultimately he did not sell the brand. [[File:Pierre Cardin et Régis Campo, Institut de France.jpg|thumb|Pierre Cardin and the French composer Régis Campo, from Académie des beaux-arts, Institut de France, Paris]] ==Automobiles== [[File:1972 AMC Javelin with Pierre Cardin interior.JPG|thumb|right|Cardin interior in a 1972 [[AMC Javelin]]]] Cardin entered [[industrial design]] by developing thirteen basic design "themes" that would be applied to various products, each consistently recognizable and carrying his name and logo.{{cite journal|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=_6EiAQAAMAAJ&q=Pierre+Cardin+Javelin&dq=Pierre+Cardin+Javelin |page=44 |title=Pierre Cardin Goes Industrial |journal=Business Week |year=1972 |accessdate=7 August 2012 }} He expanded into new markets that "to most Paris fashion designers, it is rank heresy." The business initiatives included a contract with [[American Motors|American Motors Corporation]] (AMC). Following the success of the [[Aldo Gucci]] designed [[AMC Hornet|Hornet Sportabout]] station wagon interiors, the [[automotive industry|automaker]] incorporated Cardin's theme on the [[AMC Javelin]] starting in mid-1972.{{cite journal|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=u-YCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=Pierre+Cardin+Javelin |page=45 |journal=New York Magazine |date=20 March 1972 |title=Introducing the Cardin Javelin |accessdate=7 August 2012 }} This was one of the first American cars to offer a special trim package created by a famous French fashion designer. It was daring and outlandish design "with some of the wildest fabrics and patterns ever seen in any American car".{{cite book |last=Mitchell |first=Larry G. |title=AMC Muscle Cars |publisher=MotorBooks/MBI Publishing |year=2000 |pages=55–56 |isbn=978-0-7603-0761-8 }} The original sales estimate by AMC was for 2,500 haute couture "[[pony car|pony]]" and [[muscle car]]s.{{cite book|last=Mays |first=James C. |title=The Savvy Guide to Buying Collector Cars at Auction |publisher=Indy-Tech Publishing |year=2006 |page=28 |isbn=978-0-7906-1322-2 }} The special interior option was continued on the 1973 model year Javelins.{{cite journal|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=VNQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA119&lpg=PA119&dq=Pierre+Cardin+Javelin |page=119 |last=Lamm |first=Michael |title=AMC: Hornet hatchback leads the lineup |journal=Popular Mechanics |volume=138 |issue=4 |date=October 1972 |accessdate=7 August 2012 }} During the two model years, a total of 4,152 AMC Javelins received this bold mirrored, multi-colored pleated stripe pattern in tones of Chinese red, plum, white, and silver that were set against a black background.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=r9j7MWLE_jMC&pg=PA125&lpg=PA125&dq=Pierre+Cardin+Javelin+4152 |title= The Cars of American Motors: An Illustrated History |first=Marc |last=Cranswick |publisher=McFarland |year=2012 |page=112; 125; 247 |isbn=978-0-7864-4672-8 |accessdate=7 August 2012 }} The Cardin Javelins also came with the designer's emblems on the front fenders and had a limited selection of exterior colors (Trans Am Red, Snow White, Stardust Silver, Diamond Blue, and Wild Plum) to coordinate with the special interiors.{{cite journal |last=Foster |first=Patrick |title=Pierre Cardin Meets the Javelin |journal=Hemming's Classic Car |number=31 |date=April 2007 }} However, 12 Cardin optioned cars were special ordered in Midnight Black paint. ==Other interests== [[File:Pierre Cardin 1978.JPG|thumb|left|Cardin signing his new executive jet design (1978)]] Continuously fascinated by geometric shapes, in 1975, Cardin applied his fetish for the bubble to a monumental domestic work which would become the [[Palais Bulles]] (the Bubble House), along with the help of architect [[Antti Lovag]]. Cardin furnished the Bubble House with his original creations. The curves of the Bubble House extend over 1,200 square metres and contain ten bedrooms decorated by contemporary artists, as well as a panoramic living room. Cardin bought [[Maxim's Paris|Maxim's restaurants]] in 1981 and soon opened branches in New York, London, and Beijing (1983). A chain of [[Maxim's Paris|Maxim's Hotels]] (Palm Springs, California, 1986) are now included in the assets. He has also licensed a wide range of food products under that name. During the 1980s and until the mid-1990s, he supported a French Press organization for [[Music-hall]], [[Circus]], [[Dance]] and [[Arts]] presided by a well known journalist in France, [[:fr:Jacqueline Cartier|Jacqueline Cartier]], with authors or notable personalities as [[Guy des Cars]], [[:fr:Francis Fehr|Francis Fehr]], [[Yves Mourousi]] and [[Jean-Pierre Thiollet]]. In 2001, Cardin purchased the ruins of the castle in [[Lacoste, Vaucluse]] that was once inhabited by the [[Marquis de Sade]]; he has partially renovated the site and holds music or dance festivals (particularly with [[Marie-Claude Pietragalla]]) there.{{cite news |last=Lichfield |first=John |title=Does Lacoste want the grand designs of Pierre Cardin? Non merci |newspaper=The Independent |date=19 August 2009 |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/does-lacoste-want-the-grand-designs-of-pierre-cardin-inon-mercii-1774053.html |accessdate=19 January 2010}} Cardin also owns a palazzo in [[Venice]] named Ca' Bragadin. Although he has claimed in several interviews that this house was once owned by [[Giacomo Casanova]], in reality it was the home of Giovanni Bragadin di San Cassian, Bishop of Verona and Patriarch of Venice. ==Personal life== Cardin is gay.http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/2001/01/06/pierre-cardin-ero-gay-la-moreau-mi.htmlhttp://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/exhibitions/gay-fashion-icons/http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/exhibitions/gay-fashion-icons/item-651637.aspxhttps://www.nytimes.com/2005/12/08/fashion/thursdaystyles/in-fashion-who-really-gets-ahead.htmlhttps://www.pinterest.co.uk/philpatrin/gay-out-and-proud-fashion-designers/ == Biography == * [[Sylvana Lorenz]], ''Biographie de Pierre Cardin'' (Paris: éditions Calmann-Lévy, 2006) {{fr}} == Distinctions == * {{Flag|Monaco}} : [[Commander (order)|Commander]] of the [[Order of Cultural Merit (Monaco)|Order of Cultural Merit]] (2007)[http://www.legimonaco.mc/Dataweb/jourmon.nsf/100ab120e52ceb84c12568ce002f2909/047dff856b8a8e25c125739c004969cc!OpenDocument Sov. Ord. n° 1396 of 18 Nov. 2007] : promotions or nominations : [http://www.legimonaco.mc/Dataweb/jourmon.nsf/100ab120e52ceb84c12568ce002f2909/047dff856b8a8e25c125739c004969cc/$FILE/JO7835%20m%C3%A9dailles9.pdf recipients] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} *{{cite book|last=Hesse|first=Jean-Pascal|title=Pierre Cardin: 60 Years of Innovation|year=2010|publisher=Assouline|isbn=978-2-7594-0424-7}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Pierre Cardin}} *[http://www.pierrecardin.com/ Pierre Cardin official website] *[http://www.fascineshion.com/en/fashion-close-up/pierre-cardin/314/ Pierre Cardin rare interview] *[http://www.fascineshion.com/en/exhibition/pierre-cardin-museum/318/ Pierre Cardin Museum] {{Designer labels}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cardin, Pierre}} [[Category:French businesspeople in fashion]] [[Category:French fashion designers]] [[Category:1922 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of Cultural Merit (Monaco)]] [[Category:Fashion accessory brands]] [[Category:Foreign Members of the Russian Academy of Arts]] [[Category:High fashion brands]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to France]] [[Category:LGBT fashion designers]] [[Category:LGBT people from Italy]] [[Category:Luxury brands]] [[Category:Eyewear brands of France]] [[Category:Members of the Académie des beaux-arts]] [[Category:Menswear designers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Francysk Skaryna]] [[Category:Dior]] [[Category:People from the Province of Treviso]] [[Category:FAO Goodwill ambassadors]] [[Category:20th-century French businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century French businesspeople]] [[Category:UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors]]

revision.comment: /* An American movement */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Women's Art Journal → Woman's Art Journal
revision.text:
{{About|the art style|the racehorse|Precisionist (horse)}} [[Image:Demuth Charles Aucassiu and Nicolette 1921.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Charles Demuth]], ''Aucassin and Nicolette,'' oil on canvas, 1921]] '''Precisionism''' was the first indigenous [[modern art]] movement in the [[United States]] and an early American contribution to the rise of [[Modernism]]. The Precisionist style, which first emerged after [[World War I]] and was at the height of its popularity during the 1920s and early 1930s, celebrated the new American landscape of [[skyscraper]]s, bridges, and factories in a form that has also been called "Cubist-Realism."<ref>Milton Brown, ''American Painting from the Armory Show to the Depression'' (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1955), p. 114-115.</ref> The term "Precisionism" was first coined in the mid-1920s, possibly by [[Museum of Modern Art]] director Alfred H. Barr.<ref>Gail Stavitsky, ''Precisionism in America, 1915-1941: Reordering Reality'' (New York: Abrams, 1994), p. 21.</ref> Painters working in this style were also known as the "Immaculates," which was the more commonly used term at the time.<ref>Stavitsky, p. 19.</ref> The stiffness of both art-historical labels suggests the difficulties contemporary critics had in attempting to characterize these artists.
== An American movement == [[File:NY Met demuth figure 5 gold.JPG|thumb|left|[[Charles Demuth]], ''[[I Saw the Figure 5 in Gold]]'', 1928, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]]]
Influenced by [[Cubism]] and [[futurism (art)|Futurism]], Precisionism took for its main themes [[industrialisation]] and the modernization of the American landscape, the structures of which were depicted in precise, sharply defined geometrical forms. Precisionist artists considered themselves strictly American and some were reluctant to acknowledge their European artistic influences.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/TOAH/hd/prec/hd_prec.htm Metropolitan Museum of Art]</ref> Yet it was readily apparent at the time that the fracturing of planes in many Precisionist paintings originates in the Cubism of [[Picasso]] and [[Léger]]; similarly, Precisionist renderings of shafts of light as rigidly drawn "lines of force" is a clear borrowing from Futurism. In the end, Precisionism was less about pure originality of expression and more about an energetic American use and amalgamation of certain European modernist techniques. Part of precisionism's originality is found in its subject matter and outlook.
There is a degree of reverence for the industrial age in the movement, but social commentary was not fundamental to the style. Like [[Pop Art]], Precisionism has on occasion been interpreted as a criticism of the de-natured society it portrays, though its artists did not often feel comfortable with this reading of their work. [[Elsie Driggs]]' ''Pittsburgh'' (1926) illustrates this gap in perception.<ref>For a fuller discussion of ''Pittsburgh'', see Constance Kimmerle, ''Elsie Driggs: The Quick and the Classical'' (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2008), pp. 31-33 and John Loughery, "Blending the Classical and the Modern: The Art of Elsie Driggs," ''Woman's Art Journal'' (Winter 1987), p 24.</ref> A painting of black and gray steel-mill smokestacks, thick piping, and crisscrossing wires, with only clouds of smoke to relieve the severity of the image, viewers have been tempted to see this dark painting as a statement of environmental concern. To the contrary, Driggs always claimed that she intended an ironic beauty in the image and referred to it as "my [[El Greco]]." Upon seeing the painting, Charles Daniel dubbed her "one of the new classicists."<ref>Kimmerle, p. 32.</ref> More often than not, Precisionism implicitly celebrated man-made dynamism and new technologies. Possible exceptions to this statement are some of the darker, more claustrophobic city paintings of [[Louis Lozowick]] and the comic anti-capitalist satires of [[Preston Dickinson]].
As might be expected, varying degrees of abstraction are found in Precisionist works. ''[[I Saw the Figure 5 in Gold|The Figure 5 in Gold]]'' (1928) by [[Charles Demuth]], a clamorous hommage to [[William Carlos Williams]]' imagist poem about a fire truck is abstract and stylized, while the paintings of [[Charles Sheeler]] sometimes verge on a form of [[photorealism]]. (In addition to his meticulously detailed paintings like ''River Rouge Plant'' and ''American Landscape'', Sheeler, like his friend [[Paul Strand]], also created sharp-focus photographs of factories and public buildings.<ref>[http://www.artfacts.net/index.php/pageType/exhibitionInfo/exhibition/16202 Charles Sheeler photo, retrieved online November 9, 2008]</ref>) The majority of Precisionist paintings and drawings, however, present no obstacles in identifying their imagery. Some Precisionist work tended toward a ''"highly controlled approach to technique and form"'' as well as an application of ''"[[hard-edge painting|hard-edged]] style to long-familiar American scenes"''.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/TOAH/hd/prec/hd_prec.htm Metropolitan Museum of Art]</ref> Precisionist artists aimed to convey the geometric and psychological essence of a scene or a structure but intended that essence to be almost immediately accessible.
Most Precisionist imagery is urban: office towers, apartment houses, bridges, tunnels, subway platforms, streets, the skyline and grid of the modern city. Other artists, however, such as Charles Demuth, Niles Spencer, [[Ralston Crawford]], [[Sanford Ross]], and Charles Sheeler, applied the same approach to more pastoral settings and painted starkly geometric renderings of barns, cottages, country roads, and farm houses. Artists such as [[Stuart Davis (painter)|Stuart Davis]] and [[Gerald Murphy]] painted Precisionist still lifes as well.
==Precisionists== [[File:Wall Street by Paul Strand, 1915.jpg|thumb|[[Paul Strand]], ''[[Wall Street (photograph)|Wall Street]],'' 1915]] Many American artists worked in a Precisionist style over a twenty-year period. [[George Ault]], [[Ralston Crawford]], [[Francis Criss]], [[Stuart Davis (painter)|Stuart Davis]], [[Charles Demuth]], [[Preston Dickinson]], [[Elsie Driggs]], [[Louis Lozowick]], [[Gerald Murphy]], [[Charles Sheeler]], [[Niles Spencer]], [[Morton Schamberg]] and [[Joseph Stella]], were among the most prominent Precisionists.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C04EED81439F932A25751C1A962958260&fta=y The New York Times, Roberta Smith, ''ART VIEW: Precisionism And a Few Of Its Friends," October 26, 2008]</ref> Examples of their work can be found in most major American museum collections. [[Dale Nichols]], [[Millard Sheets]],<ref>[https://www.kcet.org/shows/artbound/hilbert-museum-chapman-california-scene-paintings The Hilbert Museum reveals treasures of California Scene Painting, Liz Goldner, February 24, 2016 KCET https://www.kcet.org/ ]</ref> [[Virginia Berresford]], [[Henry Billings]], [[Peter Blume]], [[Stefan Hirsch]], [[Edmund Lewandowski]], [[John Storrs]], [[Miklos Suba]], Sandor Bernath, [[Herman Trunk]], [[Arnold Wiltz]], [[Clarence Holbrook Carter]], Edgar Corbridge and the photographers [[Paul Strand]] and [[Lewis Hine]] were other artists associated with Precisionism. The movement had no major presence outside the United States, although it did influence [[Australian art]] where [[Jeffrey Smart]] adopted its principles. Although no manifesto was ever created, some of the artists were friends and frequently exhibited at the same galleries. [[Georgia O'Keeffe]], especially with paintings like ''New York City with Moon'' (1926) and ''The Shelton With Sun Spots'' (1926), created her own more sensuous version of Precisionism, although her best-known works are not closely related to Precisionism, and it would be inaccurate to state that O'Keeffe (who vehemently resisted movement ties) was closely aligned with the Precisionist movement. Her husband, photographer and art dealer [[Alfred Stieglitz]], was a highly regarded mentor for the group and was especially supportive of Paul Strand.
Precisionist art would have an indirect influence on the later styles known as [[magic realism]], [[pop art]], and [[photorealism]], but it was largely considered a dated "period style" by the 1950s, though its influence on advertising imagery and stage and set design continued throughout the twentieth century. Its two most famous practitioners are Charles Demuth and Charles Sheeler.
==Quotations== * "America is the country of the art of the future. ... Look at the skyscrapers! Has Europe anything to show more beautiful than this?" – Marcel Duchamp, 1915 * "Since machinery is the soul of the modern world, and since the genius of machinery attains its highest expression in America, why is it not reasonable to believe that in America the art of the future will flower most brilliantly?" – Francis Picabia, 1915
==Gallery== <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Morton Livingston Schamberg - Telephone (1916).jpg|[[Morton Schamberg]], ''Telephone,'' 1916, oil on canvas, [[Columbus Museum of Art]]. File:Head Woodcut 1920.jpg|[[John Storrs]], ''Profile Head with Cap'', c. 1918, woodcut on paper [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] File:Joseph Stella, 1919-20, Brooklyn Bridge, oil on canvas, 215.3 x 194.6 cm, Yale University Art Gallery.jpg|[[Joseph Stella]], ''Brooklyn Bridge,'' 1919–1920, [[Yale University Art Gallery]] Image:Davis_Stuart_Lucky_Strike_1921.jpg|[[Stuart Davis (painter)|Stuart Davis]], ''Lucky Strike,'' 1921, oil on canvas, [[Museum of Modern Art]] [[New York City]] Image:Davis steeple street.jpg|[[Stuart Davis (painter)|Stuart Davis]], ''Steeple and Street'', 1922, [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]], [[Washington, DC.]] Image:Demuth_Charles_Incense of a New Church, 1921.jpg|[[Charles Demuth]], ''Incense of a New Church'' (1921) Image:Demuth_Charles_Chimney_and_Watertower_1931.jpg|[[Charles Demuth]], ''Chimney and Watertower,'' oil on composition board, 1931, [[Amon Carter Museum]], [[Fort Worth, Texas]] File:Skyscrapers_Sheeler_1922.jpg|[[Charles Sheeler]], ''Skyscrapers'' (1922) </gallery>
==References==
{{Reflist}}
==Sources== * Friedman, Martin L. ''The Precisionist View in American Art''. Minneapolis: Walker Art Center, 1960. * Harnsberger, R.S. ''Ten Precisionist Artists: Annotated Bibliographies [Art Reference Collection no. 14]''. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1992. * Hughes, Robert. ''American Visions: The Epic History of Art in America''. New York; Knopf, 1994. * Kimmerle, Constance. ''Elsie Driggs: The Quick and the Classical.'' Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2008. * Stavitsky, Gail. ''Precisionism in America, 1915–1941: Reordering Reality''. New York: Abrams, 1994. * Tsujimoto, K. ''Images of America: Precisionist Painting and Modern Photography''. Seattle: University of Washington Press, 1982.
==Further reading== * [[Hilton Kramer|Kramer, Hilton]], 1982, ''Precisionism Revised'' in ''Revenge of the Philistines, Art & Culture 1972 -1984''. Free Press September 12, 2007, {{ISBN|1416576932}}
==External links== * [http://www.artcyclopedia.com/history/precisionism.html Artcyclopedia] * [http://www.metmuseum.org/TOAH/hi/hi_precis.htm Metropolitan Museum of Art] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120305025312/http://www.danielhlee.com/precisionists/ Precisionists - Consummate Anti-Expressionists]
{{Westernart}}

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2015}} }} [[File:Writing on a grain of rice.jpg|thumb|A person writing on a grain of rice.]] '''Rice writing''' is the art and skill of being able to write small enough to write on a grain of [[rice]].
==History== Rice writing originated in Ancient [[Anatolia]] in Turkey and India. Many rituals and rites use rice as a medium, but at some point in ancient [[Anatolia]] artisans who were skilled in making miniature paintings decided to turn their skill to making art with what had always been an ancient symbol of prosperity, the oldest example of which lies in [[Topkapi Palace]] in Istanbul, Turkey. The artisans would inscribe messages or names on a single grain of rice after it was treated and polished. Grains that were long and flat were favorites as they offered proper surfaces for writing. Apart from Turkey, India also had a large number of artisans skilled in making miniature art including rice art.
==Rice art Symbolism== Rice art is considered to bring good luck hence some of its most popular forms is good luck pendants, hope bracelets and cell phone charms.
==Rice art and Rice jewelry today== [[File:Grain of rice necklace-2.jpg|thumb|A necklace containing a grain of rice with the name "Filip" written on it.]] Within time rice writing and rice art evolved, soon creating rice jewelry where the rice grain was enclosed in a vial with a liquid/oil that magnifies the individual grain making it easier to appreciate the painstaking and intricate details. This went further with rice jewelry like good luck pendants, charm bracelets, anklets and earrings. In modern times most of these artisans and artists set up shop with street side stalls where they can personally write your message or name on a rice grain while displaying their wares and hard work.
==Technique== Most modern day rice writers use the following tools: #Common long grain white rice: This rice is a flat cylinder shape. Because it is flat it provides two wide surfaces for writing. #Sharp utility knife: This is used to scrape the rice slightly to remove ridges to provide a smooth surface for writing. This scraping method can also be used to remove minor mistakes. #[[Clay]]: Some people use a utility gripper clay and others use a modeling clay. The clay is used to hold the rice in place while performing the writing. #[[Technical pen]]: This is a drawing pen with an ultra-fine tip. Most pens used are either size .18 (4x0) or .13 (6x0). These can be purchased online, or at some arts and crafts stores. #Waterproof Ink: This ink is sold with the technical pen.
Once the rice writing is complete, it is usually preserved in a small vial of liquid/oil. Many craftsman mount these vials into [[jewelery]] such as necklaces, bracelets and key chains.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Writing media]] [[Category:Calligraphy]] [[Category:Artistic techniques]] [[Category:Asian art]] [[Category:Rice]]

[[File:Saraiki Ajrak.jpg|thumb|300px]] [[File:Saraike Ajrak.jpg|thumb|300px]] [[File:Saraiki Ajrak 1.jpg|thumb|300px]] [[File:Saraiky Ajrak.jpg|thumb|300px]] [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Saraiki_Bool,%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A6%DB%8C%DA%A9%DB%8C_%D9%BB%D9%88%D9%84.jpg] '''Saraiki Ajraks''' [[(سرائیکی اجرک)]]<ref name="ur:سرائیکی اجرک سجرک">[[:ur:سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک)]]</ref> have become a symbol of the [[Saraiki culture]] and traditions.<ref name="wikimedia">{{cite web|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Saraike_Ajrak.jpg|title=Image: Saraike_Ajrak.jpg|publisher=commons.wikimedia.org|accessdate=2015-09-04}}</ref> On 6 March Saraiki ajrak day is celebrated. Ajrak is a name given to a unique form of blockprinted shawls and tiles found in the Saraiki belt (Saraikistan/Saraiki Waseb),<ref>[[Pakistan]]</ref> [[Pakistan]].<ref>[[Saraiki literature]]</ref> These shawls display special designs and patterns made using block printing by stamps.<ref name="urducolumnsonline">{{cite web|url=http://www.urducolumnsonline.com/zahoor-ahmed-dharija-columns/165756/saraiki-festival-aur-ajrak|title=Saraiki Festival Aur Ajrak by Zahoor Ahmed Dharija|publisher=urducolumnsonline.com|accessdate=2015-09-04}}</ref> Common colours used while making these patterns may include but are not limited to blue, red, black, yellow and green۔ Dark blue colour is the dominated one in the saraiki culture. Saraiki Ajrak is dark blue.<ref name="ur:سرائیکی اجرک سجرک"/> The blue colour makes it distinctive among other Ajraks. [[Saraiki nationalism|Saraiki]] nationalists designed the Saraiki Ajrak. Nationalists captured the heart of Saraiki belt, which Saraikies are proud on. The [[Sindh]]i [[Ajrak]] was used long ago. Some people call it sajrk, but the majority know the name of the "Saraiki Ajrak".<ref name="wikimedia2">{{cite web|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Saraiki_Ajrak_1.jpg|title=Image: Saraiki_Ajrak_1.jpg|publisher=commons.wikimedia.org|accessdate=2015-09-04}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
==See also==
*[[Saraiki literature]] *[[Ajrak]] *[[Saraiki people]] *[[:ur:سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک)|سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک)]] *{{cite web|url=http://www.urducolumnsonline.com/zahoor-ahmed-dharija-columns/165756/saraiki-festival-aur-ajrak|title=Saraiki Festival Aur Ajrak by Zahoor Ahmed Dharija|publisher=urducolumnsonline.com|accessdate=2015-09-04}} *[[:ur:سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک)|سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک]] *[[:ur:سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک)|سرائیکی اجرک (سجرک)]] [http://e.jang.com.pk/04-14-2015/multan/page12.asp]

page.title: Saturday Night Live parodies of Donald Trump

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Saturday Night Live'' parodies of Donald Trump}} [[Image:Three Donalds.jpg|thumb|[[Taran Killam]] (left) and [[Darrell Hammond]] (right), respectively, portray [[Donald Trump]] while the real Donald Trump (middle) hosted ''Saturday Night Live'' on November 7, 2015]] {{Donald Trump series}} The sketch comedy television series ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' (''SNL'') has parodied [[Donald Trump]] since 1988, from his time as a real estate broker, to his popular run as host of ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]'', and ultimately during [[Presidency of Donald Trump|his presidency]].
To date, Trump has been portrayed by five ''SNL'' performers: [[Phil Hartman]], [[Darrell Hammond]], [[Jason Sudeikis]], [[Taran Killam]], and [[Alec Baldwin]]. Darrell Hammond has portrayed him the longest, originally while in the cast in the late 1990s, and then reprising the role in a series of cameos in 2016. The other cast-members held the role briefly, with five appearances by Hartman, three by Killam, and only one by Sudeikis.<ref name="snlarchives.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?727|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Donald Trump|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> Since October 2016, the role has been played by Alec Baldwin, who has made many appearances on the series through its run.
''SNL'' has frequently paired parodies of Trump with impressions of [[Family of Donald Trump|his wives and children]] or, since he took office, various staff-members. Trump has hosted the show twice, in 2004 and 2015, the latter time as a candidate.
==Hartman parodies (1988–1990)== Cast member [[Phil Hartman]] was the show's first portrayer of Donald Trump, from 1988 until 1990. Hartman portrayed Trump five times,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?727|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Donald Trump|publisher=|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> and was paired with [[Jan Hooks]] as Trump's then-wife [[Ivana Trump]] or, in one case, [[Marla Maples]], Trump's second-wife-to-be.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?727|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Ivana Trump|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="people.com">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/article/history-of-donald-trump-on-snl/|title='I'm a Ratings Machine': A History of Donald Trump on SNL|date=3 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
The first sketch, from December 1988, shows Donald and Ivana celebrating Christmas, giving large, gold and jewel-encrusted presents to each other.<ref name="people.com"/>
Trump is seen in the audience at the ''[[Saturday Night Live 15th Anniversary Special]]'' from 1989, where [[Chevy Chase]] spills popcorn on him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideedition.com/headlines/12399-watch-the-donald-trump-sketch-that-was-mysteriously-deleted-from-2004-snl-episode|title=Watch The Donald Trump Sketch That Was Mysteriously Deleted From 2004 SNL Episode|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref>
A sketch from February 1990 parodies the Ivana Trump divorce. Ivana demands more money since Donald has been unfaithful, but he refutes this by referring to their extensive [[prenuptial agreement]]. It states, among other things, that he is entitled to have mistresses provided they are younger than she is, and that she will be paid in [[Rai stones|giant stonecoins]].<ref name="people.com"/>
The next episode had Marla Maples and Trump appearing on ''[[The Church Lady|Church Chat]]''. The couple are referred to as a "satanic sandwich", and the sketch shows press coverage of their relationship, including a "Best Sex I've Ever Had" headline.<ref name="people.com"/>
==Hammond parodies (1999–2011, 2015–2016)== Hartman did not do more Trump-sketches after 1990, and [[Darrell Hammond]]'s first two portrayals came in 1999.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/article/history-of-donald-trump-on-snl/|title='I'm a Ratings Machine': A History of Donald Trump on SNL|date=3 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> The first sketch had [[Ross Perot]] ([[Cheri Oteri]]) searching for "a new crazy leader" for the [[Reform Party of the United States of America|Reform Party]], with Trump and [[Pat Buchanan]] ([[Chris Parnell]]) as possible candidates. Their meeting is crashed by a violent [[Jesse Ventura]] ([[Will Ferrell]]). In the second sketch Trump announces [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000|that he is running for president]] and tells the audience, "Eh, don't try to fight it. Alright?" He also introduces his running mate, ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'' winner [[John Carpenter (game show contestant)|John Carpenter]].
Hammond resumed playing Trump in 2004, doing so a total of 16 times up to 2011, although he left the cast in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?1721|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Donald Trump|publisher=|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> His parodies focused on Trump's interest and involvement with politics, commercials, and his appearances on [[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|''The Apprentice'']]. Trump [[Saturday Night Live (season 29)#ep561|hosted the show]] in April 2004, praising Hammond in his opening monologue, and appeared in a sketch next to Hammond's Trump.
An early 2005 episode introduced Trump's third wife, [[Melania Trump|Melania]] ([[Paris Hilton]]). Trump brings her home to let his children, [[Eric Trump]] ([[Fred Armisen]]), [[Donald Trump Jr.]] ([[Seth Meyers]]), and [[Ivanka Trump]] ([[Maya Rudolph]]), "meet their new mommy". Melania would be portrayed later by [[Molly Shannon]] and, from 2015 and onward (without Hammond), by [[Cecily Strong]].<ref name="snlarchives.net1">{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?3603|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Melania Trump|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Hammond is the show's longest running Trump impersonator. He played the role for ten years in the cast, 1999 to 2009, and reprised it twice in 2011. In the 2011 sketches Trump involves himself in the upcoming [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2012|Republican Party presidential primaries]] and questions [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories#Donald Trump|President Obama's birth certificate]].
After returning to serve as the show's announcer in 2014, he began reprising his role as Trump regularly, beginning in December 2015. Due to the wide field of GOP candidates in the [[2016 U.S. presidential election]], the show needed at least one cameo appearance to cover all of the candidates. Taran Killam, who at this point had begun playing Trump, switched to portraying [[Ted Cruz]]. ''SNL'' had asked alumnus [[Jimmy Fallon]] (who had portrayed Trump on [[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon|his own show]]) to play the part.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://screencrush.com/snl-donald-trump-jimmy-fallon-darrell-hammond/|title=SNL Wanted Jimmy Fallon to Take Over Trump From Taran Killam|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> When a last minute change prevented this, Hammond returned to the role. [[Cecily Strong]], who had portrayed Melania opposite Killam's Trump, continued in this role alongside Hammond.<ref name="snlarchives.net1"/>
Hammond subsequently appeared as Trump in seven more episodes of the season. His appearance in the role was critically acclaimed,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/01/25/why-snl-can-t-quit-darrell-hammond-its-best-donald-trump-impersonator.html|title=Why 'SNL' Can't Quit Darrell Hammond, Its Best Donald Trump Impersonator|first=Matt|last=Wilstein|date=25 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> but some outlets reported that the role should be moved to a permanent cast member at some point.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/beck-bennett-donald-trump-snl/|title=Beck Bennett Should Play Donald Trump When SNL Returns|date=21 September 2016|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Sudeikis parody (2012)== [[Jason Sudeikis]] appeared in the role once, during a ''[[Fox & Friends]]'' parody.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?3266|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Donald Trump|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> Sudeikis' Trump comments on Barack Obama's handling of [[Hurricane Sandy]].
==Killam parodies (2015)== It was announced prior to the show's forty-first season that [[Taran Killam]] would be taking over the role for the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Reportedly, several cast members had auditioned for the role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/09/taran-killam-donald-trump-saturday-night-live-nbc-1201537233/|title=Taran Killam To Play Donald Trump On 'Saturday Night Live'|first=Nellie|last=Andreeva|date=20 September 2015|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Killam's Trump debuted on the October 2015 sketch "A Message From Donald & Melania Trump", which also introduced Cecily Strong as Melania Trump. The message is sent from "our humble gold house", and Donald presents himself as "the man who's almost certainly your next president". The couple praise Donald's qualities as a person and a politician, although he becomes uncomfortable when she claims that he [[Political positions of Donald Trump#In his own words|"was democrat before he was republican"]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Episodes/?201510031|title=SNL Archives - Episodes - 10.03.2015 #1|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> The duo reprised the setup and characters in December, wishing viewers a Merry Christmas and presenting a "Naughty and Nice" list. Donald placed Santa on the "naughty" list since he doesn't trust anybody who can fly over a wall.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Episodes/?201512051|title=SNL Archives - Episodes - 12.05.2015 #1|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Donald Trump [[Saturday Night Live (season 41)#ep791|hosted ''SNL'' a second time]] in November 2015, and Killam and Hammond appeared during the opening monologue alongside him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Episodes/?201511072|title=SNL Archives - Episodes - 11.07.2015 #2|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> Since Trump was running for president, his appearance triggered the [[equal-time rule]], so his opponents received free air time on NBC affiliate stations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/11/20/media/donald-trump-snl-equal-time/index.html|title=Donald Trump says 'SNL' was 'biased' and asks for 'equal time for us'|first=Frank|last=Pallotta|date=20 November 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref> Trump appeared in a sketch portraying him as an incredibly successful president in 2018. Cecily Strong parodied Melania, and Trump's daughter Ivanka appeared in a cameo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcdfw.com/entertainment/entertainment-news/Saturday-Night-Live-Trumps-The-Donald-343030352.html|title='Saturday Night Live' Trumps 'The Donald'|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref> Trump ends the sketch by telling the audience that his ''actual'' presidency would be even better. Trump is one of 17 presidential candidates who have appeared on Saturday Night Live, and the only American President to have hosted the show.<ref>Serico, Chris. Star-spangled laughter: 17 presidential candidates who appeared on 'SNL'. TODAY. 6 November 2015. Web. <http://www.today.com/popculture/star-spangled-laughter-17-presidential-candidates-who-appeared-snl-t54106> Retrieved 26 July 2017.</ref> Killam later expressed regret and shame for what he referred to as "normalizing" Trump's candidacy.<ref>Sanders, Sam. [https://www.npr.org/2017/10/17/558160262/taran-killam-says-there-was-never-any-common-ground-when-trump-hosted-snl "Taran Killam Says 'There Was Never Any Common Ground' When Trump Hosted 'SNL.'"] ''NPR''. 17 October 2017. 17 October 2017.</ref>
For the December 19, 2015 episode (co-hosted by [[Tina Fey]] and [[Amy Poehler]]), ''SNL'' lacked enough cast members to portray all of the GOP candidates in a debate sketch. As a result, [[Jimmy Fallon]] was asked to return in the role of Trump (which he had played many times on ''The Tonight Show'') so that Killam could portray [[Ted Cruz]] instead. Ultimately, that plan fell through at the last minute, and instead, Hammond played Trump in the debate.
Hammond continued to play Trump for the remainder of the season. Killam's contract was terminated early after that season, with some news sources alleging that being replaced as Trump was part of the reason.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/08/why-saturday-night-live-shook-things-up/495104/|title=Why Taran Killam and Jay Pharoah are Leaving 'Saturday Night Live'|first=David|last=Sims|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
==Baldwin parodies (2016–present)== In September 2016, ''SNL'' announced that [[Alec Baldwin]] would replace Hammond in portraying Trump in its parodies of the [[2016 presidential debates]]. Hammond had not expected this, and was very shaken by the replacement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/style/2017/09/27/darrell-hammond-was-snls-best-donald-trump-and-its-best-impressionist-ever-so-what-went-wrong/|title=Darrell Hammond was SNL's best Donald Trump – and its best impressionist ever. So what went wrong?|publisher=}}</ref> Baldwin has continued portraying Trump in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BK6W7uJguop/|title=Instagram video by Saturday Night Live - SNL • Sep 28, 2016 at 7:46pm UTC|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snlarchives.net/Impressions/?3692|title=SNL Archives - Impressions - Donald Trump|publisher=|accessdate=25 January 2017}}</ref> Unlike his predecessors, he has never been a cast-member, but as of February 2017 he has hosted the show 17 times, more than anyone else.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/02/10/media/saturday-night-live-alec-baldwin-trump-preview/|title=Alec Baldwin returns to host an 'SNL' that he and Trump have made great again|first=Frank|last=Pallotta|publisher=}}</ref> Baldwin received a [[Critics' Choice Television Award|Critics' Choice Award]] and a [[Primetime Emmy Award]] for his portrayal of Trump.<ref name="ew.com">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/01/15/donald-trump-slams-snl-again/|title=Donald Trump Slams 'SNL' Again: 'The Worst of NBC'|date=15 January 2017|publisher=|accessdate=25 January 2017}}</ref>
===Before election===
Baldwin's Trump debuted in the October 1, 2016 episode, opposite [[Kate McKinnon]] as [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[Michael Che]] as debate moderator [[Lester Holt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/02/arts/television/snl-premiere-donald-trump-alec-baldwin.html|title='S.N.L.' Begins a New Season With Alec Baldwin as Donald Trump|date=2 October 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> The sketch was based on the [[United States presidential debates, 2016#First presidential debate (Hofstra University)|first presidential debate]] between Clinton and Trump. The episode also included impressions of members of Trump's family in a parody of the game show ''[[Family Feud]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/saturday-night-live-returns-alec-baldwin-donald-trump-article-1.2814204|title='Saturday Night Live' returns with Alec Baldwin as Donald Trump|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Further sketches with Baldwin included elements of the other presidential debates, [[United States presidential debates, 2016#vice presidential debate (Longwood University)|the vice presidential debate]], and the [[Donald Trump and Billy Bush recording controversy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.truthdig.com/avbooth/item/saturday_night_live_tackles_vp_debate_donald_trump_sexism_scandal_20161009|title='Saturday Night Live' Tackles the VP Debate and Donald Trump's Sexism Scandal (Video)|date=9 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
The October 15 episode featured a parody of the third presidential debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4532596/snl-donald-trump-alec-baldwin-hillary-clinton-debate/|title=Watch Saturday Night Live's Take on the Second Presidential Debate|first=Mahita|last=Gajanan|publisher=|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> Later in the episode, Baldwin and Cecily Strong appeared as Donald and Melania Trump, in a parody of [[Beyoncé]]'s [[Lemonade (Beyoncé album)|''Lemonade'']]. Host [[Emily Blunt]] portrayed [[Ivanka Trump]], and [[Vanessa Bayer]] appeared as Trump's youngest daughter [[Tiffany Trump]].
Trump reacted negatively to this episode on Twitter, saying that Baldwin's portrayal "stinks", and that it was "time to retire the boring and unfunny show."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/10/16/heres-the-snl-that-finally-went-too-far-for-donald-trump/|title=Here's the SNL sketch that finally went too far for Donald Trump|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite tweet|user=realDonaldTrump|number=787612552654155776|date=16 October 2016|title=Watched Saturday Night Live hit job on me.Time to retire the boring and unfunny show. Alec Baldwin portrayal stinks. Media rigging election!}}</ref>
===After election===
Post-election sketches have included Baldwin's Trump meeting with people such as the [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]], [[Mitt Romney]], and [[Vladimir Putin]], with humor drawn from the [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|2016 United States election interference by Russia]]. In February, it was reported that the show has had strong viewer ratings since the election.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/saturday-night-live-ratings-18-49-demo-melissa-mccarthy-1201978637/|title='Saturday Night Live' Flexes Post-Election Ratings Muscle|first=Cynthia|last=Littleton|date=5 February 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
Several people who work closely with Trump have been frequently parodied. These include [[Counselor to the President]] [[Kellyanne Conway]] (Kate McKinnon),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/12/the-feedback-loop-of-saturday-night-live-and-donald-trump/509618/|title=The Feedback Loop of 'Saturday Night Live' and Donald Trump|first=David|last=Sims|publisher=|accessdate=5 February 2017}}</ref> [[White House Chief Strategist]] [[Steve Bannon]] ([[Mikey Day]]) with a [[Grim Reaper]]-like appearance,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/steve-bannon-snl-grim-reaper-60-minutes-hurt-feelings-a7940301.html|title=Steve Bannon discusses SNL portraying him as the Grim Reaper|date=11 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=23 November 2017}}</ref> [[White House Press Secretary|White House Press Secretaries]] [[Sean Spicer]] ([[Melissa McCarthy]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/why-melissa-mccarthy-made-a-great-sean-spicer|title=Why Melissa McCarthy Made a Great Sean Spicer|date=7 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/06/opinions/sean-spicer-cupp/index.html|title=Sean Spicer has a problem: Melissa McCarthy|first=S. E.|last=Cupp|publisher=|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> and [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] ([[Aidy Bryant]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/11/05/snl-gives-sarah-huckabee-sanders-the-full-sean-spicer-treatment/|title=Analysis - SNL gives Sarah Huckabee Sanders the Sean Spicer treatment|first=Aaron|last=Blake|date=5 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=23 November 2017|via=www.washingtonpost.com}}</ref> and [[United States Attorney General]] [[Jeff Sessions]] (Kate McKinnon).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/19/arts/television/snl-al-franken.html|title='Saturday Night Live' Takes Aim at Al Franken, an 'S.N.L.' Alumnus|publisher=|accessdate=23 November 2017|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2017/11/12/roy-moore-too-creepy-jeff-sessions-snl-cold-open/856139001/|title='SNL': Jeff Sessions tells Roy Moore, 'I'm usually the creepiest one in the room'|publisher=|accessdate=23 November 2017}}</ref> [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Mike Pence]] is portrayed by [[Beck Bennett]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2017/10/15/saturday-night-live-alec-baldwins-trump-demands-pence-walk-out-everything/759913001/|title='Saturday Night Live': Alec Baldwin's Trump demands Pence walk out of everything|publisher=|accessdate=23 November 2017}}</ref> and Trump's sons Eric and Donald Jr by [[Alex Moffat (comedian)|Alex Moffat]] and [[Mikey Day]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/entertainment/a13303713/eric-donald-trump-jr-snl-weekend-update/|title=Eric and Donald Trump Jr. Joined SNL's Weekend Update to Discuss the Mueller Charges|date=5 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=23 November 2017}}</ref>
Trump tweeted his displeasure with the show in November, December, and January, saying "Totally biased, not funny and the Baldwin impersonation just can't get any worse." and "NBCNews is bad but Saturday Night Live is the worst of NBC. Not funny, cast is terrible, always a complete hit job. Really bad television!".<ref name="ew.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-trailguide-updates-alec-baldwin-fires-back-with-some-1479680568-htmlstory.html|title=Alec Baldwin fires back with some presidential advice after Trump angrily tweets about 'SNL'|first=Jessica|last=Roy|publisher=|accessdate=25 January 2017|via=LA Times}}</ref>
In January 2017, ''SNL'' writer [[Katie Rich]] was suspended from the show after she wrote a joking tweet saying that Trump's youngest son, [[Family of Donald Trump#Barron Trump|Barron]], would become "this country's first [[School shooting|home school shooter]]." The tweet provoked significant outrage, and Rich apologized, calling it "inexcusable".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2017/01/23/snl-writer-suspended-apologizes-barron-trump-tweet/96963720/|title='SNL' writer suspended, apologizes for Barron Trump tweet|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2017/01/23/after-barron-trump-homeschool-shooter-tweet-snl-writer-deletes-her-account/|title=SNL writer suspended for Barron Trump tweet, writes apology: 'It was inexcusable'|first1=Emily|last1=Yahr|first2=Emily|last2=Yahr|date=23 January 2017|publisher=|accessdate=26 January 2017|via=washingtonpost.com}}</ref>
''[[El Nacional (Santo Domingo)|El Nacional]]'', a [[Dominican republic|Dominican]] newspaper, mistakenly published Baldwin's picture instead of Trump's in February. The paper quickly apologized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-dominican-paper-alec-baldwin-donald-trump-20170211-story.html|title=Dominican paper apologizes for using Alec Baldwin photo for Donald Trump|first=Associated|last=Press|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/02/11/trump-baldwin-dominican-paper-gets-wrong/97799548/|title=Trump or Baldwin? Dominican paper gets it wrong|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Saturday Night Live parodies of Bill Clinton|''Saturday Night Live'' parodies of Bill Clinton]] * [[Saturday Night Live parodies of Hillary Clinton|''Saturday Night Live'' parodies of Hillary Clinton]] * [[Saturday Night Live parodies of Sarah Palin|''Saturday Night Live'' parodies of Sarah Palin]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
